channel.title: missouri on HERESY LEVAIN
channel.description: Latest experiments in missouri from HERESY LEVAIN

item.title: Dr. Funkenstein
item.description: A zero-waste science experiment to salvage a batch of unbeloved Karl92 wheat, through a long fermendation. It metamorphosed into a whole wheat alveolate ecstasy that you never knew existed.
item.content:
A few weeks ago, I got some organic Karl92 wheat from Richard, grown by a local farmer.

Karl92 is a modern high-quality HRWW variety, selected from “Karl” by R. G. Sears, leader of the Manhattan wheat program from 1982 to 2000. Karl92 has higher yield and better disease resistance than the OG variety. Protein content is ~12%.

This lot of Karl92 got invaded by wild onions while still growing in the fields, and the wheat berries picked up an oniony aroma. I thought naturally onion-scented wheat was quite interesting – I wondered if it would be a great flour for a herbaceous bread. There’s a niche market for everything. If I were to market this batch of Karl92, I would label them “Funkadelic Ecstasy organic whole wheat: kissed by wild onions, ingrained with Mother Earth’s inherent magic.” Coastal foodies and food snobs would go crazy about it. No doubt. FWIW, there’s a toy company that sells squishy onions – stress balls in the shape and color of a red onion and, when you squish them, they actually release onion scents to encourage further stress relief.

I also got a batch of Karl92 whole wheat flour that was milled a while ago and starting to smell musty. I know, 99% of people would just toss it in the trash. But the zero-waster in me was curious whether this batch of flour could be salvaged through fermentation.

So I dumped the flour (1,722g) on a BBQ grill, and let it smoke over a bunch of corn husks for a few hours. The smelly flour picked up a nutty, endearing, almost bacon-y aroma. Then I sifted the smoked flour twice: got 237g coarse bran (14%) out the first time, and 220g middlings (13%) the second time, leaving 1,265g flour (73% extraction).

I divided the 237g coarse bran into

  • 200g: for levain
  • 37g: for dusting/coating

And thus began my cosmic adventure into the funky world of Karl92.

Levain: 425g

2 builds, in 24h:

ingredient weight
coarse bran 200g
boiling water 200g
diastatic barley malt 5g
sourdough starter, stiff WW 20g

Pour boiling water over the coarse bran in a gass bowl. Mix well. Let it sit for a few hours.

You can add the malt while the bran soaker has cooled off some, but add the starter only after the bran soaker has cooled off completely to room temperature.

Based on my previous baking experiments and consumption of scientific studies, the most effective way to process the bran and improve its texture is sourdough starter + alpha amylase + xylanase, let sit for 24 hours at 24¬∞C/75¬∞F. (I’ve done this many times on oat hull fiber and have achieved good results. I have a friend who’s pathologically obsessed with “volume eating”, e.g., consuming large volumes of food while taking in minimal calories at the same time. Oat fiber is insanely popular among these volume-eaters, because the boatload of fiber in it increases the volume of food while adding zero net carbs or calories.)

Depending on the genotype, dry wheat bran can contain about 50% dietary fiber and 9%-25% starch. Most of that dietary fiber in bran is insoluble fiber (hemicelluloses):

  • arabinoxylans (~55%)
  • celluloses (9-12%)
  • lignins (3-5%)
  • fructans (3-4%)
  • Œ≤-glucans (2.2-2.6%).

Most arabinoxylans are water-unextractable, but a smaller part is water-extractable. Cellulose is insoluble and resistant to many microorganisms and enzymes. Celluloses are often associated with lignins and other non-starchy polysaccharides. Together with lignin and other fibers, cellulose forms a lignocellulose, which is highly resistant towards degradation. Fructans and Œ≤-glucans are the main components of the soluble fiber.

Xylanase is an enzyme that can degrade or break down the xylans in insoluble fiber and convert them into a simple sugar (xylose), which then can be metabolized by the yeast and lactic acid bacteria. In the end, this makes insoluble fiber less capable of interfering with and diluting the gluten in grains, so the bread won’t lose much volume or taste.

Amylase is another enzyme that breaks down starches, polysaccharides, and complex carbohydrates into easier-to-absorb simple sugars.

Diastatic barley malt packs in amylase and some endogenous xylanase, while wheat bran itself also contains xylanase and laccase.

Grain kernels themselves usually contain a certain amount of endogenous xylanases for re-modeling and expansion of cell walls during normal cell growth and for more drastic cell wall degradation during seed germination. Additionally, grains also contain microbial xylanases from micro-organisms populating the outer grain kernels layers.

Industrial production of xylanases is mostly manufactured via submerged fermentation of lignocellulolytic substrates such as barley husk, corn cobs, hay, wheat bran or straw.

Scalded soaker: 1,100g

Soak the middlings from the second sift in hot water for 24h.

ingredient weight
middlings 220g
boiling water (4x bran weight) 880g

I usually give the coarse bits a prolonged, unconstrained hydration to completely satisfy their thirst, before I get the final dough going. (I ended up having to retard both the bran levain and the soaker in the fridge after the first 24 hours, due to traveling.)

Final dough

When you incorporate the levain and the scalded soaker into the final dough, you add every part of the grain back. Not one bit is wasted. Therefore, this bread retains its whole-grain integrity.

ingredient weight
sifted Karl92 flour 1,265g
scalded soaker 1,100g
water 120g
levain 425g
salt 30g

No autolyse this time. I simply amalgamated everything and left the shaggy mess in the fridge overnight, √†‚Äé la Jim Lahey’s no-knead method.

Another reason I didn’t feel like working the dough: The gluten in the sifted Karl92 flour had deteriorated to the point where it performed almost like a pastry flour. The dough was very sticky even at such low hydration.

If you must calculate the hydration percentage:

  • excluding levain: 1,000g/1,485g = 67%
  • including levain: 1,210g/1,700g = 71%

The next day, I took the dough out of the fridge and gave it a stretch & fold. Time and cool temperatures worked their magic on the dough – it was coming together on its own without much manual coaxing.

A few hours later, I pulled the dough out again and laminated it with caramelized onions (not drained), wheat berries1, and bread spices2. I let the dough rest in the cold until bedtime and gave it a coil-fold. Afterwards, I left it undisturbed in the fridge for 72 hours.

The overall process was basically similar to what I did with the Turkey Red bread, but at a significantly slower pace.

ingredient weight baker’s percentage
flour3 1,485g (1,265g flour + 220g middlings) 100%
water 1,000g (880g + 120g) 67%
levain 425g 29%
salt 30g 2%
onions 80g 5.4%
spices 20g 1.3%
wheat berries 107g 7.2%

I decided to go for a 72h fermentation for a few reasons:

  • to reduce as much mycotoxin as possible through prolonged lactic acid bacteria fermentation;
  • to mask the musty smell/taste via developing a complex web of flavors;
  • to see how long the gluten could hold together before it started to break down.

72+ hours later, I took the dough out of the fridge and pre-shaped it loosely. The dough had risen by ~30% but felt chock full of air. It hadn’t become a soup, so I guess the gluten hadn’t collapsed. After a 1-hour bench rest, I shaped it tight (using the reserved 37g coarse bran as coating) and let it proof at room temperature until 100% risen. It took about 5 hours.

Then I baked it as usual, in the toaster oven. The dough weighed 3,187g (7.08 lbs) before baking.

It turned out a monstrous loaf: It measured about 11"x9"x5" and weighed just under 6 lbs. after cooling.

Hipsters might call this a miche, a.k.a. the fancy Parisian way of denoting “a supersized rustic sourdough bread,” which is in fact a French slang for “butt-cheek.”

The sweet aroma of freshly baked bread wafted through the whole house – one of my all-time favorite smells. I let the bread sit in a brown paper bag overnight before slicing.

Crumb reveal

The bread was a breeze to cut into. The knife came out clean. A very distinctive and pleasant fragrance immediately hit the nose.

The crumb turned out much more aerated than in the Turkey Red loaf and had some large holes; it was also much lighter and fluffier, although a bit less moist, than the TR. (High hydration level promotes bigger holes, but the high percentage of whole grain flours works against them.)

I don’t want to sound like a food snob, but I have to confess that the only words I could think of when slicing this bread were “alveolate ecstasy.” Each slice felt ethereal, almost weightless, on my hand. In any case, this was a great crumb for sandwiches and toasts.

Now, the flavor: I was struck first by the tender, airy texture – so delicate on my tongue that it felt like eating cottony clouds – although there was some nice chew, too.

Like the Turkey Red loaf, there was little wheat flavor. Maybe there was, but it was easily overshadowed by a prominent combination of sourness and tanginess. I would describe it as noticeably more tangy than sour – it likely contained a wider spectrum of piquancy than I could articulate – and I would compare it to a sour rye bread or even a tamarind/lemon juice combination. Call it a pane picante integrale?

The brisk flavors of caramelized onions (or was it the wild onions looming in the Karl92?) and crushed spices came through and were nearly assertive enough to go mano a mano with the lush tartness.

The wheat berries had literally melted into the crumb and were content to stay in the background.

The crust was thin, crispy, and chewy except for the ears which crunched. It tasted much more flavorful than the crumb, as usual, and added the nuttiness I always enjoy.

All in all, I think the long, cold fermentation resulted in a fortified crust giving way to richly complex layers of bold, indulgent, sophisticated flavors. Lots of nutty, earthy and sweet overtones followed by a deep tanginess and a trace of pleasing bitterness. I’m a huge fan of zing and heat, and this bread hit the spot!

Best part: I didn’t smell or taste any mustiness in it no matter how hard I tried, nor did we feel sick at all from eating it.

We devoured half of the loaf in 3 days (delicious as is, but even better toasted), and took the rest to a BBQ at the relatives yesterday. They all grew up eating pre-sliced Wonder Bread (or Bunny¬Æ Bread, which – I just learned yesterday – has been a household name and an iconic brand in the Midwest for decades, no offense) and have vastly different food preferences than me.

Everybody loved the texture of the bread; they thought it was almost as soft and fluffy as the premium mediocre Bunny¬Æ Original 100% Whole Wheat Bread! Lol. This may sound like an insult to a coastal foodie, but in a Midwestern context it must be interpreted as the highest form of compliment – because “you can’t beat the Bunny!”

However, nobody liked the pungent flavor of this bread. Someone compared it to balsamic vinegar, and someone else said it tasted as sour as Trolli sour gummy worms (“for people who can’t get enough tanginess in their life”). Still, the bread disappeared quickly – maybe people just got intense carb cravings.

Oh well. That was fun.

Guess I have just found another failproof (and easier) way of making whole wheat “clouds,” besides the method I accidentally discovered while making panettone integrale. What I have done with Karl92 over the last couple of weeks – from smoking the flour to sifting to the 72h fermentation – is fairly labor-intensive and time-consuming, not something I’d do often or use for production. Just a science experiment for my own curiosity.

  1. Spices consisted of dill seeds, caraway seeds, fennel seeds, coriander, fenugreek seeds, anise, black peppercorns, and papaya seeds; all roasted and coarsely ground just before using. ↩︎

  2. I soaked a handful of funky Karl92 wheat berries in liquid whey, and let it ferment for a few days. Drained and incorporated the mushy berries (wet weight 107g). ↩︎

  3. With 220g midds added back, the total amount of flour used directly in the dough stood at 1,485g (~86% extraction). ↩︎

item.title: The Wheatwalker
item.description: My first foray into baking with heirloom wheat: an experimental open-crumb wheaty bread made with locally grown and milled Turkey Red, the OG American wheat.
item.content:
I recently took a trip to CoMo (Columbia, MO) to visit Richard Kapp’s lovely farm and mill. The moment Richard told me he had local Turkey Red, I was hooked. I had no idea Turkey Red could be grown in central Missouri.

Richard shared a lot of stories about local agriculture: growing hard wheats in Missouri is more challenging than selling bicycles in Alaska, because of the climate, soil, distribution, uncompetitive commercial potential, dearth of local interests, etc. The University of Missouri is far less keen on hard wheat trials and researches than Kansas and Nebraska.

Richard also gave me a nice tour of his farm, and kindly offered me a sample of his freshly milled organic Turkey Red flour (85% extraction) to try. This batch of Turkey Red was grown by Paul Lehmann, an organic farmer in Fayette (~25 miles northwest of CoMo).

The OG American wheat

Turkey Red is a type of hard red winter wheat brought to Kansas by Mennonite immigrants from Russia, the part now known as Ukraine, in the late 1870s. It ended up becoming the primary wheat variety grown in the Midwest for the next ~70 years. It grew especially well in Kansas and, by the early 20th century, was planted in more than 75% of the fields. (Hard red winter wheat was widely grown in the Great Plains area with Kansas as the center, and became known as “Kansas wheat.")

After World War II, as industrial farming and the “Green Revolution” started taking hold, this heritage variety faded away. Wheat began to be hybridized for yield and depend on the application of fertilizers, herbicides, pesticides, etc. The increase in productivity, in many cases, come at the cost of flavor and nutrition.

There is speculation that the changes made during hybridization altered the protein and gluten structure of the grain, which has made modern hybrid wheat more difficult to digest and is thought to be the cause of gluten-intolerence in many people.

Unlike modern high-yielding dwarf wheat varieties, Turkey Red grows very tall, creating lots of straw and biomass for the soil. It’s a landrace variety, i.e. it contains genetic diversity making it adaptable across bio-regions. Fortunately, Turkey Red seeds were saved and this heritage wheat is making a comeback in many parts of the Midwest. It’s one of the most popular revival wheats used by US bakers, treasured for its flavor and digestibility.

There is actually a museum in Goessel, Kansas dedicated to the Mennonite farmers who brought over Turkey Red seeds from Russia in 1874.

Master formula

Total Turkey Red flour used: 450g (440g in the dough + 10g bran for dusting)

ingredient total weight baker’s %
flour 440g 100%
water 380g 86%
levain 88g 20%
salt 9g 2%
spent grains1 45g 10%
raisins 20g 4.5%

Dusting:

ingredient weight
reserved bran 10g

Process:

process time
bran soaking 12 hours (75¬∞F)
autolyse 6 hours (60¬∞F)
bulk ferment 14 hours (44¬∞F)
final proof 3 hours (75¬∞F)
bake 1 hour

I used extended bran soaking, high hydration, and retarded cold fermentation in this dough to help draw out the natural flavors of heritage wheat flours.

Day 1

10pm

Sift 450g of the 85% extraction Turkey Red flour into

  • 400g flour (~75% extraction)
  • 50g bran & germ
    • 40g: for hot soaker
    • 10g: for dusting later

Even though the 85% extraction flour has already been sifted, it still contains a fair amount of the bran and germ which can’t be milled as finely as the starch and can stand in the way of gluten formation.

Still, you want to hang on to every bit of these, because they contain important nutrients as well as a nuanced flavor from the local terroir.

Make a scalded soaker:

ingredient weight
bran & germ 40g
boiling water 160g

Mix well and let sit, covered, at room temperature for 12-18 hours.

Day 2

1pm

Mix together:

ingredient weight
sifted ~75% extraction flour 400g
scalded soaker 200g
cold water (50¬∞F) 200g

Mix well and autolyze at 60¬∞F for ~6 hours.

7pm

After ~6 hours of cool autolyse, mix the final dough.

Add 88g of stiff whole wheat levain (60% hydration). Slap & fold for 5-7 mins.

Add the salt and 20g of water (bassinage), mix and squeeze for another 5-10 mins until completely absorbed. The dough is very tacky but should start to feel some strength by the end of this mixing.

Place the worked dough in a fridge (44¬∞F) immediately. Cold bulk-ferment for the next 14 hours. Do 3 sets of stretch & fold, at 30 minutes apart, during the first 2 hours. My dough felt very extensible, although not very strong.

At the 3-hour mark, laminate the dough with spent grains (not drained) √† la German biertreberbrot and chopped raisins.

My dough almost passed the “windowpane” test!

At the 4-hour mark, perform a coil-fold.

Remove 10g of the dough and put in an aliquot jar for easy measuring. Place the aliquot next to the dough in the same bowl, and return both to the fridge. Leave them undisturbed overnight.

Day 3

9am

Remove the dough from fridge, and pre-shape via a loose coil-fold. Both the dough and the aliquot have risen a little bit overnight.

Rest for 45-60 minutes.

10am

Shape the dough tightly and place in a proofing vessle. I put mine in a loaf pan lined with parchment paper.

Let the dough rest for 2-3 hours at room temperature, until the aliquot portion has risen nearly 100%. Mine took ~3 hours to get there.

Note: Watch the dough not the clock! Move at the dough’s pace.

1pm

Time to bake!

I did 15 minutes at 375F in the toaster oven, followed by another 35 minutes at 300F.

The dough had a pretty decent oven spring. It actually rose more than I expected and emitted some intoxicating wheat aroma!

When the bread was done baking, it sounded hollow when I firmly thumped the¬†bottom with my fingers.

Should’ve slashed a little deeper, huh?

Let the bread cool.

Size of the baked bread: 8” x 5" x 4".

Day 4

3pm

After 24 hours of cooling and curing, came the moment of truth…

The crunchy crust has softened overnight and is quite easy to cut into. The knife comes out mostly clean.

The crumb is fairly open. No gaping holes, but a very nice texture. Moist, tender, pillowy, and springy. I’m surprised how light it is.

The crumb surrounding the raisins tastes mildly tangy but flavorful – almost like a small amount of caraway seeds and cinnamon has been added. Scattered raisins give you random bursts of sweetness.

The spent grains impart a subtle malty flavor and nutty crunch every now and then when you hit a berry. In case you are wondering, it does not taste like beer at all. You just get some extra fiber from the spent grains.

The crust is thin, crisp, chewy and firm, and tastes much more flavorful (sweet, cinnamony notes).

The extended hydration of bran and long autolyse really helped with gluten development. The dough needed quite a bit of coaxing at the beginning, but gradually fell into place. A cool, long fermentation helped to develop a light texture and a complex flavor.

Overall, this is a wheaty loaf that doesn’t taste dense or earthy like other almost whole wheat loaves. It has a lingering flavor that is just incredible.

This Turkey Red from CoMo is absolutely delicious. The high-quality soil these grains are grown in and the freshness of the flour contribute a rich, unmistakable nuttiness and depth of flavor to the bread.

  1. The spent grains were a wet mush from a local craft brewery, consisting of 1/2 white wheat malt and 1/2 pilsner malt. ↩︎

item.title: Orange Sunshine
item.description: A seedelicious bread made with 100% Warthog whole wheat flour and a bucket of orange juice.
item.content:
The first time I ate homemade bread was in 2011 in Kansas City, when I was backpacking across the US. I had no idea that bread was something you could make at home. Prior to that, my experience with bread had been exclusively limited to the typical white mush served at school cafeterias. It was so disgustingly bland, empty, and unfulfilling – not to mention it was also emblematic of everything that was wrong with America – that I developed a sort of White Bread PTSD and swore I’d never eat another slice of bread after college.

Funny how the Covid lockdown has inspired/forced a lot of people to bake breads at home – and even sell their homemade breads on Etsy. It has forced me to pay more attention to where I source my food from and whether they will always be available.

A number of artisan-ish bakeries across the country are selling their bread flours nicely packaged in eco-friendly brown paper bags at “pandemic special” prices, to make up for their lost business & revenue due to the shutdown and retain customer relationships.

Last month, King Arthur Flour rebranded itself to King Arthur Baking Company. The flour company was founded in 1790, and is America’s first flour company. They have re-aligned the company to reflect their mission – “bake joy.” King Arthur is now a lifestyle company, like Lululemon, Peloton and Chipotle. I don’t buy King Arthur’s flours or care for its recipes, but I do find that rebranding – particularly the timing – interesting.

Literally every state has a “local” flagship producer. IL has Janie’s. NY has Farmer Ground Flour. OR has Camas Country Mill. NC has Carolina Ground. TX has Barton Springs Mill. AZ has Hayden Flour Mills. Who is MO’s local artisan flagship producer?

If I were going to bring coastal friends “Missouri-grown” non-touristy gifts, I wouldn’t know what to get – other than t-ravs, provel, and maybe some local booze. I know the MO Department of Agriculture has a program called Missouri Grown, but the local goodies gift box it has put together is a joke.

Missouri always feels like a giant black hole of locally grown grains. Sure, Missouri grows a ton of soybeans, corn and soft wheat. I mean, it’s a Corn Belt state. But most of them are exported via the Mississippi River, and the rest processed into animal feed, industrial inputs, and biofuels. Only a tiny percentage stays local. The US Soybean Export Council and American Soybean Association (which has a political action committee called SoyPAC) are both headquartered in St. Louis (STL). Monsanto was founded in STL and headquartered here for over 100 years, and its new parent, Bayer AG, still established its North American HQ here. The world’s biggest grain traders – Archer Daniel Midland (ADM), Bunge, and Cargill – all have major operations in STL as well. (These 3, along with Louis Dreyfus, control ~90% of global grain trade and have enormous power over grain prices.) Evidently, their presence here impacts local farmers and agri-food system.

Missouri certainly doesn’t have a shortage of local producers, and the flagship local product with (inter)national recognition doesn’t have to be bread wheat – South Carolina has done exceptionally well with heirloom rice renaissance, for example.

I had the good fortune of living a stone’s throw away from Anson Mills in Charleston for a number of years, and got to witness its metamorphosis to the Palmetto State’s flagship artisan producer/purveyor, an explosive commercial success with international fame. Tourists from all over the world flock to Charleston, SC to visit Anson Mills and experience the antebellum culinary past. It has become a culinary tourist destination in and of itself. More incredibly, the entrepreneurs behind Anson Mills are not even SC natives. What’s the MO equivalent of Anson Mills or Carolina Gold rice, or of even San Francisco’s Tartine? My point is, MO local producers have a branding/PR problem. Tom Cruise is a globally recognizable brand. Janie’s of Illinois is a national brand. What’s the most recognizable MO brand? The only local product brand (even remotely) familiar to people from out of state or overseas might be Hammons Black Walnuts, which does have a D2C web store, but its branding and packaging leave a lot to be desired.

Kansas City (the Wheat Belt’s buckle) seems rife for a “single-origin wheat” renaissance that will help rebuild local economy and reclaim the Wheat State’s agricultural heritage. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Kansas City had dozens of flour mills. Grain magnate Frank A. Theis (namesake of Theis Park) wrote in a 1938 article in The Kansas City Star, “No other industry, directly or indirectly, has been more closely identified with the growth of Kansas City.” In South Carolina and North Carolina, the cultivation of revival grains is a rapidly expanding enterprise.

I desperately wanted to find a Missouri-grown bread wheat. I went on a relentless hunt for this elusive prize, with little success. All neighboring states grow bread wheats, why not Missouri? My curiosity took me down a rabbit hole… What started out as a seemingly trivial question turned into a herculean quest and then Mission Impossible.

Obviously, most people buy flours, not grains. So flour was where I started.

A bearded guitarist and baker used to sell his sourdough breads at farmers' markets and some restaurants in STL. One of his breads was pan bigio, an Italian country loaf made with “local Cape Girardeau whole wheat flour.” I tried to find out which Cape Girardeau farm/mill that was (since I wasn’t aware there even was one), but he shut down his operations in March and went dark.

I called up the few artisan-ish bakeries in STL that pride themselves on using “locally grown and milled wheat” to ask what flours they use and where they source them from. Not only did they refuse to tell me anything, but also they got very confused and in some cases suspicious… as if I had broken an unspoken cultural taboo. One of the nicer bakers directed me to the proverbial purveyors of “unique local organic artisanal products,” aka. specialty retailers that label everything with 10+ haute adjectives and lists everything 1,000% higher than MSRP. Well, that was a very curious experience. I’m not sure whether these bakeries 1) genuinely use local ingredients as much as they claim, 2) severely lack business acumen to begin with, or 3) are simply too small-minded and uncreative.

I went back to the drawing board and started doing some research, when I found out that the band, from Delaware, Maryland, northern Virginia and southern Illinois and through Missouri to the eastern part of Kansas, is known for growing soft winter wheat. In fact, whatever wheat ends up flourishing on a commercially viable scale in Missouri is usually soft winter wheat and mostly exported, although Mizzou Cooperative Extension’s hard winter wheat trials in several locations around the state are successful. Most of the commercial bakeries here source their bread flours by truckloads from western Kansas.

After a few days of hopeless internet research, I was on the verge of giving up. Serendipitously, a couple of small farms in central/western MO came across my radar – they grow organic hard red winter wheat!

So this is how I found 180 Farms in Sweet Springs, MO. I called up Greg Guier earlier last week week, to inquire about his organic wheat berries. Holy shit, Greg is one of the nicest and most down-to-earth people I’ve ever talked to. Some Midwesterners are just frighteningly friendly! He told me this year’s Warthog Red, a hard red winter wheat, was still being harvested and would be ready in a few days, and last year’s Darby White, a hard white winter wheat, was readily available. He said he delivers only to Kansas City, because he tried for years to set up delivery arrangements in STL but couldn’t get anyone interested.

I was going camping in the Ozarks this weekend anyway, so I took a detour and stopped by Greg’s farm to scoop up some freshly harvested Warthog wheat berries. (Heck, even swung by the Overland Park Farmer’s Market and procured some heritage Meishan pork from Odd Bird Farm in Weston, MO.) Turns out, that was a great decision.

Warthog is a modern HRWW with a moderate protein content (10%-11%). I remember Warthog was hugely popular at the NYC Greenmarket a few years ago (thanks to GrowNYC Grains, a distributor/hub that promotes and sells local grains in the Northeast). Farmer-miller Thor Oechsner planted Warthog for the first time in 2010, loved it, and grew to become the largest Warthog producer in the Northeast. Then Janie’s Mill picked it up, too.

I did read about Warthog’s relatively low protein level for a HRWW, and kept that in mind while working with the flour. In fact, Oechsner recommended blending Warthog with a spring wheat flour to boost protein content while letting Warthog’s special flavor shine through.

Nah. I’m gonna go Warthog all the way through.

First step: mill the Warthog wheat berries several times to get the finest grind possible.

ingredient baker’s %
whole wheat flour (Warthog - 180 Farms, MO) 100%
rye levain 40%
water 42%
fresh orange juice 42%
diastatic barley malt powder 1%
flaxseeds, freshly ground 5%
salt 2%
soaker 33%
seed mix (for coating) 5%

The science behind incorporating orange juice and diastatic malt is explained in a later post. TL;DR: Diastatic malt increases the conversion of starches to sugar, boosting the caramelization of the crust. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) in orange juice tightens the gluten network and gives the bread a better rise.

Soaker:

ingredient baker’s %
quinoa 25%
sunflower seeds 25%
whole flax seeds 25%
black sesame seeds 25%
orange juice 150%

You know my usual M.O.

The crumb doesn’t look too bad. Excuse my cutting.

Pretty darn tender and juicy.

Yum, the flavor is superb.

A great backpacking bread.
